Comments_List: This was a great course for solidifying your knowledge in Linear Algebra.
Better familiarity with linear algebra as well as some understanding of control theory.
Analytical skills of analyzing a linear system.
I learned a lot from this course, albeit through sheer willpower, and supplemental linear algebra/analysis/control theory from the web.

I learned to analyze the properties of a linear system, examining for the key attributes "observability, controllability, and stability", by looking at eigenvalues of some matrices which describe that system.

Weaknesses: The homework comes to a point where it's impossible to do with just the notes and other resources. You will need to seek help for problems. The TA was very helpful for this. 

Strengths: Review of LA is great.
I thought the organization was strong and the problems were well crafted. I think adding in more examples/applications to motivate why we are doing the linear algebra would be helpful.
Class notes are super math-y in terms of notation. So, some concepts can be confusing upon first read.

Strength: 
The course gives good theoretical background to begin reading algorithms (control systems, some types of machine learning) papers. 

Weakness:
This course is very abstract. Nobody knows how to use this information, so people had limited motivation to learn beyond "studying for the test." The professor mentioned many cases where controls are used, but it is very unclear how the specific course content is useful.

Improve:
The course should present some more algorithms, at least as optional reading which we can then use during a discussion day in class time or in a review session with the TA's. I know students can bring in some random algorithm and discuss with the TA, but it is much more efficient if there is a shared knowledge base where we know the TA has familiarity with the paper we want to learn about. This could be as simple as choosing three popular algorithms that every controls person should know, and a few from the other popular majors of students who take this course.

This is a slippery slope. Some things in the class were very useful, other things were certainly useless. If you would like to suffer for a semester with assignments every week that take up to 15 hours (a few were much shorter), then this class is what you need to understand linear systems. I would recommend given certain situations. This is not really a class you take for 'fun', but one you can see yourself utilizing the concepts with later on.
It depends on what they're interested in. Honestly, I think much of what we did does not apply all that well to my area of study.
I won't recommend this course to students who will not be doing analytical work in the future.

Take this course only if you have a decent background in linear algebra, or if you are willing to learn it in tandem with the class. The problem sets take a significant amount of time and are very challenging. The tests are straightforward and much easier than the problem sets.

No. I have no idea how the material is useful. I'll tell them to directly take the course which motivated them to take the course. Such as an algorithms, machine learning, robotics, etc. course. These involve linear systems and/or controls, and the course description recommends the course for people with those interests.
I spent a lot of time learning about eigenvalues, but can't use the course to produce a single thing that is useful for my research.
